questiontext.text:
Sine and cosine in the four quadrants

First quadrant \((0^\circ\le\theta\le 90^\circ)\)

Below are some figures highlighting the behaviour of \(\cos \theta\) and \(\sin \theta\) as \(\theta\) moves in the first quadrant.

\(\theta = 0^\circ\). Thus \(OQ = OP =1\) and so \(\cos 0^\circ =1\). Also \(OR=0\) hence \(\sin 0^\circ = 0\).

\(0^\circ < \theta < 90^\circ\). We have \(\cos \theta = OQ\) so \(0<\cos\theta<1\). Similarly \(\sin \theta = OR\), so \(0<\sin \theta<1\).

\(\theta = 90^\circ\). Now \(OQ = 0\) so \(\cos90^\circ = 0\), and \(OR = OP = 1\), so \(\sin 90^\circ = 1\)

It follows from the figures above that \(\cos\theta\) decreases from \(1\) to \(0\) as \(OP\) rotates from the horizontal position to the vertical, i.e. as \(\theta\) increases from \(0^\circ\) to \(90^\circ\). \(\sin\theta=OR\) increases from \(0\) (when \(\theta=0^\circ\)) to \(1\) (when \(\theta=90^\circ\)).

Second quadrant \((90^\circ\le \theta\le 180^\circ)\)

Referring to the figures below, remember that it is the projections along the positive \(x\) and \(y\) axes that are used to define \(\cos\theta\) and \(\sin\theta\) respectively. It follows that as \(\theta\) increases from \(90^\circ\) to \(180^\circ, \ \cos\theta\) decreases from \(0\) to \(-1\) and \(\sin\theta\) decreases from \(1\) to \(0\).

\(\theta = 90^\circ\), so \(\cos \theta = 0\) and \(\sin \theta = 1\).

\(90^\circ < \theta < 180^\circ\). \(\cos \theta = OQ\) (negative), and \(\sin \theta = OR\) (positive).

\(\theta = 180^\circ\), then \(\cos \theta = OQ = OP = -1\) and \(\sin \theta = OR = 0\).

Considering for example an angle of \(135^\circ\), referring to the figure below, by symmetry we have:
\(\sin 135^\circ=OR=\sin 45^\circ=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\qquad \)
\( \cos 135^\circ=OQ_2=-OQ_1=-\cos 45^\circ=-\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

Key Point

\( \sin (180^\circ-x)\equiv\sin x \qquad \text{and}\qquad \cos (180^\circ-x)\equiv-\cos x \)
